Missed chances. Delayed action.
<[silence:2400]>
The "cost of hesitation" measures what you lose by waiting—time, opportunity, or advantage—like a runner pausing mid-race while others sprint ahead.

<[silence:2400]>
Hesitation often feels safe, but it’s a silent tax. In 1985, Coca-Cola’s delay in responding to Pepsi’s sweeter taste let Pepsi gain 10% market share in just two years. By the time Coke acted with "New Coke," the damage was done—customers revolted, and Pepsi’s lead stuck for decades.

<[silence:1200]>
In nature, lions hesitate for 1.2 seconds before chasing prey. That pause drops their success rate from 30% to 10%. For humans, the math is similar: a 3-second delay in braking at 60 mph adds 88 feet to stopping distance—enough to turn a near-miss into a collision.

<[silence:2400]>
The brain’s anterior cingulate cortex triggers hesitation, weighing risks. But overthinking paralyzes. Chess grandmasters lose 18% more games when they spend over 2 minutes on a move, even in complex positions. Speed, not perfection, often wins.

<[silence:1200]>
Opportunity windows close fast. In 2007, Nokia hesitated on touchscreens, calling the iPhone a "niche product." Five years later, their market share collapsed from 50% to 3%.

<[silence:2400]>
Hesitation isn’t always bad—it prevents reckless mistakes. But its cost compounds: a single paused decision can ripple into years of catch-up.

<[silence:1200]>
Decision fatigue.
The OODA loop.
Sunk cost fallacy.
